awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Statistical Optimization for Barcoding and Decoding Single-Cell Dynamics via CRISPR Gene Editing
awd_abstract_narration:
Novel genomics technologies, such as gene editing and single-cell sequencing, have brought great progress on defining the structure and function of human cells at unprecedented resolution and scale. Traditional “bulk” genomic measurements are often insufficient as sample heterogeneity and differential cell state dynamics could be masked. CRISPR-based gene-editing technology enables single-cell lineage tracking using evolvable barcodes. Building on this technology, we will address mathematical challenges arising from single-cell barcoding and decoding, by developing online optimization and single-cell time series analysis methods. This line of research would generate analytical tools for barcoded singlecell data, with provable theoretical guarantees, that are both sharable and deployable for defining the genetic basis of cellular lineage and gene expression states. Application of these tools will help uncover the complex biology behind cell evolution and interaction in health and diseases. The research includes projects suitable for student participation and training at various levels, and open-source software development. 

Current cellular barcoding tool is limited by its scalability, and the single-cell transition data made possible by the barcoding technology presents new analytical challenges. To significantly improve the capacity of cell barcoding, we will develop learning-theoretic optimization methods for efficiently finding the best barcoding design over a large combinatorial design space. Further, we will develop state embedding methods to identify mathematical abstractions of cell states from gene-expression paths, as supported by the barcoded trajectories, that imply critical cell dynamics and genetic regulation. In particular, we will use kernelized low-rank approximation and convex polytope approximation schemes to estimate metastable cell clusters and gene-expression landmarks. Finally, we will validate the dynamics decoding tools using data from real cancer model experiments. The research findings will open up new potential in biological-driven mathematical methods. They will have implications for stem-cell and developmental biology, neuroscience, immunology, and other areas of biological investigation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

How to Precisely Track Cancer Cells to Understand Drug Resistance?

Cancer is one of the most devastating diseases. While many drugs are available, patients often develop resistance, causing their cancer to return after initial treatment success. To understand how cancer cells develop drug resistance, scientists need to follow individual cells as they change over time. Researchers from Princeton and Stanford Universities have developed new tools to track thousands of cancer cells simultaneously, providing unprecedented insight into drug resistance.

This National Science Foundation-funded project combined gene editing technology with advanced computational methods. The team used CRISPR to insert unique genetic "barcodes" into cancer cells. As cells divide, these barcodes are passed to their descendants, allowing scientists to trace cellular family trees.

A major challenge was designing barcodes to label huge numbers of cells. The team developed machine learning algorithms to optimize barcode designs, dramatically increasing trackable cells. They demonstrated following over 60,000 individual cells - a massive improvement over previous methods.

The researchers applied their system to study how melanoma, an aggressive skin cancer. By analyzing genes in different cell lineages over time, they gained new insights into how some cancer cells evade treatment and continue growing. Specifically, their system's high-throughput nature allows scientists to capture rare events critical in resistance evolution. By identifying changes allowing cancer cells to survive treatment, researchers can develop new strategies to overcome or prevent resistance.

The team is sharing their technologies to accelerate cancer research, publishing detailed protocols and releasing open-source software. The project also integrated research and education, including new graduate courses and mentorship programs.

While focused on cancer drug resistance, these technologies have broader applications for studying other complex biological problems and diseases. This project has developed a powerful toolkit for understanding cancer's response to treatment, potentially leading to more effective therapies that overcome drug resistance.
